abstracts.cdata!:
The Compensatory Education Project for
            received a satisfactory outcome rating with low risk to
            development outcome. The Banks performance was rated
            moderately satisfactory while the Borrower received a
            satisfactory rating. There was one restricting that took
            place within this project. The change was a reallocation of
            funds from Categories 2 and 6 to Category 1. This change was
            requested in order to disburse the full loan before Project
            closing. There were no revisions to the PDO or project
            components. The Project provided a number of lessons that
            were considered in preparation of the follow-on operation.
            With respect to the Early Childhood Development (ECD)
            intervention, there were lessons learned about sessions
            specifically targeted at fathers, which were unsuccessful.
            Future efforts to engage fathers should be better suited to
            the cultural and gender norms that prevail in many of these
            areas. The Mobile Pedagogical Support (API) program has also
            provided valuable lessons. Since engagement with parents is
            an important element of the program, visits by APIs to
            parents will be held on weekends, in order to maximize the
            probability that fathers who work outside the village of
            origin are present, since women are less likely to receive
            the API when they are home alone. One key lesson learned
            from the program is the need for more frequent supervision
            by National Council for Educational Development (CONAFE) of
            schools targeted by the program. From an administrative
            viewpoint, expense categories under the Project did not
            correspond with Project Components, making it difficult for
            the Implementing Agency to monitor Project costs.
            Categorization of expenses by component, rather than by
            procurement category, would allow for a better understanding
            of outputs and activities by component in future projects.
